However, since his arrest, he was sentenced to possession of a mobile telephone and SIM card while being in custody and sentenced to a term of imprisonment. While Mumtaz Qaumi’s criminal history disentitles him to the leniency that would be afforded to a first offender, it does not constitute an aggravating feature or engage the principles discussed by the High Court in Veen (No 2).
	
	
	In Mumtaz Qaumi’s case, the psychiatric evidence and the history of trauma and dislocation are of some significance to an assessment of the proper sentence. [44]  They receive support from the evidence of his wife and mother. The psychiatric issues pre-date the commission of the current offences. I accept Dr Nielssen’s conclusions as to the connection between his anxiety disorder and the offences arising out of the dispute with BFL Bankstown. This impacts on his moral culpability and the weight to be afforded to general deterrence. I am not satisfied on balance that his time in custody is more onerous due his mental health issues although I accept Dr Nielssen’s assessment that the conditions of his incarceration are very onerous, a matter which became a focus of attention late in the course of the sentencing hearing.
	
	
	The long gap in Mumtaz’s criminal history (2006-2013), the support he has from his wife, the incentive to reform represented by his infant children and Dr Nielssen’s opinion that his anxiety disorder is “generally quite responsive to treatment” lead me to conclude (as did Dr Nielssen) that Mumtaz Qaumi has “reasonable prospects for longer-term rehabilitation”.
	


Jamil Qaumi


	
	Jamil Qaumi tendered a report prepared by a psychologist (Ann-Marie De Santa Brigida) and testimonials from his older sister and his wife.
	
	
	Jamil was born in 1992 and was 21 years old at the time of the offences and 25 years old at the time of sentence. He married shortly before the offences. Apart from a common assault and failing to leave the restricted area of a railway station, for which he was fined a total of $700, he has no prior convictions. The absence of a significant criminal record is a mitigating feature. However, since being taken into custody he has been sentenced for assaulting two prisoner officers by throwing water on them, pretending it was urine. He received a two month sentence for that offence.
	
	
	He was born in India and so was not directly exposed to the horrors of the Afghan war. However Ms Brigida refers to the possibility of “inter-generational transmission of trauma”. Given the post-traumatic stress suffered by his older brothers and father, I am prepared to accept this possibility although the report does not suggest any particular link between that vicarious condition and the offending. Of more significance is his exposure to violence in the form of a “drive-by” shooting when he was 13 years of age and his “allegiance” to his brothers. He has a history of substance abuse.
	
	
	Jamil’s sister (Shaista Amin) described Jamil as “very family oriented” and a “very caring person”. When Mrs Amin was diagnosed with gestational diabetes during her fifth pregnancy in 2013, Jamil “took responsibility” for her children and helped Mrs Amin with domestic life. Mrs Amin states that Jamil “made sure my [her] kids were always safe and happy”. She also described Jamil going “out of his way” to help an elderly neighbour suffering from cancer. Mrs Amin believes that Jamil committed the offences for which he is now to be sentenced “out of fear” triggered by a drive-by shooting at their home in 2006. She thinks Jamil feared that he would “lose family members for no reason”. Mrs Amin believes her brother is “deeply remorseful” for “his involvement in the death of Mahmoud Hamzy” and describes how he “sincerely regrets his offences and what he has put the victims, his own wife and our [the] family through”.
	
	
	Jamil’s wife (Farishta Qaumi) described a supportive husband and a man that had “a lot of love for his family and everyone around him”. The pair married in Islamabad, Pakistan in 2013 and remained there for 5 months until Farishta’s Australian visa was granted. Mrs Qaumi described “behavioural changes” in the weeks before his arrest. Her husband became “over protective … fearing something that he never spoke about”. Mrs Qaumi stated that she and Jamil’s family did not attend the trial as “Jamil thought it wasn’t safe”. Mrs Qaumi said that her husband “regrets his involvement in the death of Mahmoud Hamzy” and that he “feels terrible about what happened”.
	
	
	I accept the evidence of Jamil’s sister and wife and the opinions stated by the psychologist. I accept that Jamil was under the influence of his elder brothers, particularly Farhad, and that he became involved in the BFL Blacktown as a result of that connection. I am not prepared to act on the hearsay expressions of contrition and remorse. In spite of his offending since being incarcerated, misgivings arising from the various counts of contempt and the grave offending for which he is to be sentenced, his youth and family support satisfy me that he has some prospects of rehabilitation.
	


Approach to the subjective cases


	
	While family and subjective circumstances such as those I have just described are extremely moving, it is important not to lose sight of the gravity of the offending in this case. The sad personal circumstances of the offenders and their families cannot lead the court to impose a sentence that is unduly disproportionate to the crimes. Also, it is important not to forget the impact of the crimes on the individual victims and on the community more generally. I have no doubt that the number and frequency of the shootings in late 2013 caused fear in the community and did violence to people’s right to feel safe and secure as they go about their business. It is important then to record the impact on the victims and it is to that subject that I now turn.
	


the impact on the victims


	
	Many people’s lives have been affected by the outlandish and lawless violence in which these three offenders were involved over a one to two month period in latter part of 2013. Two men are dead and it is pure good fortune that more people were not killed. Many people were exposed to the gangland and gun violence instigated by the offenders. In some cases, the impact of the offenders’ conduct on the victims and their loved ones is devastating. In saying this, it must be remembered that Jamil Qaumi is not to be punished for the killing of Joseph Antoun and Farhad Qaumi is not responsible for those wounded in the Chokolatta Café shooting.
	
	
	Hassnah Hamzy is the sister of Mahmoud Hamzy. She provided a victim’s impact statement that explained her whole family’s loss and grief. [45]  She told me her brother was a beautiful soul who wouldn’t hurt a fly and that he was killed by people who didn’t even know his name because he was in the wrong place at the wrong time. Since her brother’s homicide, Hassnah has trouble coping and becomes very emotional and breaks down over little things. She says she will never be the same person she was before. She said her parents have changed and that nobody in the family will ever be the same. The family treats their lives as “before” and “after” the killing of Mahmoud. Not only have they lost their loved one, but their shared memories have been destroyed because of the way Mahmoud was killed. The family no longer enjoys family trips away, and does not celebrate religious holidays because Mahmoud’s absence is so palpable and painful. They cannot bear it.
	
	
	Omar Ajaj sustained two gunshot wounds, one to the right upper leg in the thigh region and one to the right hand side of his abdomen. A bone in his right leg was fractured. Mr Ajaj was treated by paramedics, taken to Liverpool Hospital and was not discharged until 5 November 2013. There was no issue at the trial, and the jury found, that his injuries constituted grievous bodily harm.
	
	
	Michael Odisho suffered gunshot wounds described earlier. He required surgery and appears to have made a good recovery.
	
	
	In addition to the physical injuries suffered by Mr Odisho, his mother was present when her son was shot. She gave evidence in the trial and was obviously distressed and greatly affected by the experience of a gunman coming to her home and shooting her son.
	
	
	The injuries to H (an innocent fourteen year old child) were potentially life threatening. Many hundreds of shotgun pellets were left in her body and doctors were unable to remove all of the pellets. This resulted in lead poisoning that may affect her ability to conceive a child or to carry a pregnancy to full term. Her demeanour when giving evidence, while courageous and at times feisty, showed that she was traumatised by the incident. A number of other people, including the proposed target and his family, were present when the shotgun was fired at or into their home. Again, while no evidence was adduced, it is reasonable to assume that being exposed to a shooting attack in the place they were entitled to feel safe has had an impact on each of them.
	
	
	In the Chokolatta Café shooting, two men received shotgun injuries. Abdul Abu-Mahmoud suffered “injuries caused by shotgun pellets and associated shrapnel”. These injuries were to the back of his head, neck and shoulder. The injuries were not life threatening but required surgical intervention to remove the shotgun pellets. Hassan Souid received injuries to the back of the scalp, right biceps and the back of the shoulder. [46] 
	
	
	Four victim’s impact statements were read explaining the devastation wrought on the family of Joseph Antoun. [47]  His partner, Teagan Mullins, read her own statement and also those of her two daughters. His brother, Nemer Antoun, also read a statement.
	
	
	Ms Mullens spoke of the bond between Mr Antoun and the twins and how Joe would come home every night to spend time with the girls. She has been left financially ruined and emotionally traumatised. She gave an emotional account of watching her husband die and her little girls waving as the ambulance took their father away. She suffers panic attacks and her health has been greatly affected. She and Joe were to get married the year after he was killed. The twins were to be the flower girls at the wedding. They will never have their father at school assemblies when they receive awards and will not have the example of their parents’ loving relationship to learn from and to emulate.
	
	
	The simple and moving testimonies of the little girls spoke for themselves. They miss their Dad who gave the “best cuddles”, always let them choose the movies and came home to put them to bed each night. They miss him in the morning and when they come home from school. They said it is not fun to see their mum “all emotional” when they visit their Dad at the cemetery.
	
	
	Nemer Antoun spoke of his brother who was nicknamed the White Rooster. He remembers jumping the fence with Joe to watch the Rabbitohs. He spoke of the family bond, the weekly visits Joe would make to his elderly mother and the loss to the twins. He spoke of Joe’s relationship with the Thungutti community near Kempsey where Joe was welcomed as a brother. The people there held a service for Joe after he died. Joe was murdered in cold blood in front of his wife and children and Nemer asked “For what?” and “who has the right to kill for no reason and take a man from his children or a boy from his mother?” Nemer is on a crusade for justice.
	
	
	I am grateful to the family of Joseph Antoun for their courage and openness in reading their statements to the Court. What you have told me will be taken into account in accordance with the law.
	
	
	The Crown made an application under s 28(4) of the Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act which provides:
	


“A victim impact statement given by a family victim may, on the application of the prosecutor and if the court considers it appropriate to do so, be considered and taken into account by a court in connection with the determination of the punishment for the offence on the basis that the harmful impact of the primary victim’s death on the members of the primary victim’s immediate family is an aspect of harm done to the community.”


	
	The difficulties in the application of this section, in the face of the fundamental principles that all human life is sacred and that all people are equal under the law, have been discussed in a number of cases. [48]  In R v Halloun McCallum J said of s 28(4):
	


“I would construe the new provision as an important mechanism for ensuring that the evidence of family victims is placed before the court to give texture to the undoubted proposition that every unlawful taking of a human life harms the community in some way. In that way, the provision serves the purposes of sentencing stated in s. 3A of the Act, one of which is to recognise the harm done to the victim of the crime and the community.”


	
	That comment was approved by the Court of Criminal Appeal in Sumpton v R, an appeal from a sentencing decision in which I applied her Honour’s statement of principle. On that basis, I consider it appropriate to take into account the victim’s impact statements of Hassnah Hamzy and the family of Joseph Antoun in determining the appropriate penalty on the basis that the harm done to them is an aspect of harm done to the community.
	


PRINCIPLES of sentencing


	
	The common law has developed a unified set of principles guiding the exercise of the sentencing discretion. Those principles are well established and it is not necessary to set out each and every one of them in order to satisfy the primary purpose of a judgment (or remarks) on sentence, which is to explain to the offender, the community and those affected by the crimes why a particular sentence is being imposed. Legislation in relation to sentencing makes the task more technical and complex, especially in a case like this where there are so many different offences. Even so, sentencing ought not to descend into the application of “some sort of checklist”. [49]  For example, I do not propose to go through all of the offences, addressing each and every aggravating and mitigating factor in s 21A of the Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999. It will be clear from these remarks the matters that are aggravating and those that are mitigating. Even so, it is appropriate that I set out some of the important legal principles and to explain how I have applied those principles to the particular facts and circumstances of the present case. It is also necessary to attempt to comply with the technical aspects of the sentencing legislation.
	


Purposes of punishment


	
	I must always keep in mind the purposes of sentencing and punishment. The common law principles that underpin those purposes now find, in New South Wales, statutory voice in s 3A of the Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act 1999. They are:
	



	
	To ensure that the offender is adequately punished for the offence;
	
	
	To prevent crime by deterring the offender and other persons from committing similar offences;
	
	
	To protect the community from the offender;
	
	
	To promote the rehabilitation of the offender;
	
	
	To make the offender accountable for his actions;
	
	
	To denounce the conduct of the offender; and
	
	
	To recognise the harm done to the victim of the crime and to the community.
	



	
	The weight to be given to these various purposes will vary from case to case and from offender to offender. In a case like this, involving gangland violence and homicide, general deterrence must play a significant role. The sentences imposed on these three men must send a clear message that those involved in gang violence will receive substantial punishment. Similarly, the offenders must be adequately punished and made accountable for their actions. Their conduct must be denounced. The protection of the community is important, and particularly so in the case of Farhad Qaumi in light of his criminal record and leadership of the BFL Blacktown. The harm done to the victims, and to the community, must be recognised. In view of the length of sentence that I am obliged to impose on Farhad and Mumtaz, it is difficult to see how any sentence that I could formulate would promote the rehabilitation of the two older brothers. The promotion of rehabilitation is a more significant factor in Jamil’s case because he does not face the prospect of a sentence of life imprisonment and is still a young man.
	


Aggravating and mitigating features


	
	As I have said, I will not go through each offence to check off the relevant aggravating and mitigating features identified in s 21A. However, given the abundance of litigation that s 21A has generated, I should say something general and brief about the operation of that provision. Where a matter identified as an aggravating feature in s 21A(2) is either an element of the offence or where it is inherent in that offence, it ought not to be “double counted” as an “aggravating feature” under the statute. A simple example is that the aggravating feature in s 21A(2)(c) – the use of a weapon – could not be considered to be an aggravating feature in relation to an offence of possession of a weapon or an offence of firing a firearm at a dwelling.
	
	
	In the present case, many of the offences are aggravated because they involved the use of a weapon. However, many offences of the kind charged against the offenders involve the use of a weapon and the matter ought not to be given undue weight as an aggravating feature. However, in assessing the totality of the criminality involved in this case, one of the most significant factors is the number of guns used, their ready availability and the offender’s willingness to engage others to use them to carry out crimes of extreme violence.
	
	
	Another significant aggravating factor arises in the offences that took place in peoples’ homes (the Hamzy, Odisho and Zakaria shootings) and where the offences showed a disregard for the safety of the public (the Chokolatta Café shooting). Further, all of the offences were part of a planned and organised criminal activity. I have already referred to the approach that the Court must take to organised crime and gangland violence.
	
	
	The foregoing is not an exhaustive list of aggravating features and the descriptions I have given of the offences should disclose the reasons I have formed the view as to the objective criminality of each of the offences.
	
	
	The most compelling mitigating feature in relation to each of the offenders is not dealt with under s 21A(3). This concerns, in the case of Farhad and Mumtaz Qaumi, the offenders’ personal history, their traumatic experiences in Afghanistan and the psychiatric impact this has had on each of them. It cannot be said that this meant that they were not “fully aware of the consequences of their actions” [s 21A(3)(j)]. However, it is well accepted that a history such as this “may mitigate the sentence that may otherwise be appropriate” because:
	


“ … a background of that kind may compromise the person's capacity to mature and to learn from experience. It is a feature of the person's make-up and remains relevant to the determination of the appropriate sentence, notwithstanding that the person has a long history of offending”. [50] 


	
	This “may mitigate the sentence because his or her moral culpability is likely to be less than the culpability of an offender whose formative years have not been marred in that way.” [51]  The passages I am quoting are from the High Court’s decision in Bugmy v The Queen. The High Court was there dealing with an Aboriginal offender whose development was affected by a life of deprivation and exposure to alcohol abuse but the Court was clear in saying that the relevance of such matters was not determined by the ethnicity of the offender.
	
	
	In Jamil Qaumi’s case, his youth, lack of prior convictions, previous good character and prospects of rehabilitation are relevant mitigating factors. It is also the case that he was acting under the influence of his older brothers and was “hyper vigilant” because of his exposure at a young age of a drive by shooting targeting his older brother.
	


Parity and proportionality


	
	It is a fundamental principle of equal justice that offenders who are charged with offences arising out of the same factual circumstances should receive sentences which are proportionate to one another. [52]  The principle is not restricted to situations where the offenders are charged with the same offence. [53]  An offender should not be left with a “justifiable sense of grievance” or seen to wear “the badge of unfairness” as a result of disparity between the sentences that is not justified by relevant differences. [54] 
	
	
	In the present case, the parties tendered a body of material to allow me to give effect to those principles. [55]  I have also considered the decisions in R v AC; AC v R [2017] NSWCCA 20 and R v MM; R v WK [2017] NSWCCA 19 in which the original sentencing judgments (contained in Ex S-B) were upheld on appeal. The Crown also provided a helpful table setting out the sentences imposed on co-offenders in relation to a number of the offences, the charges that each faced, the extent of any “discount” for a guilty plea or assistance to authorities, the Form 1 offences taken into account in sentence and any other offence to which any particular offender pleaded guilty. [56] 
	
	
	In two cases (Witnesses L and M), I was the sentencing judge while the remaining co-offenders (Witnesses C, D and I) were dealt with in the District Court. In many cases, the charges to which the co-offenders pleaded guilty were different (usually, but not always, less serious) than those for which the current offenders are to be sentenced. By way of example, Witness I was charged with discharging firearm with intent to cause grievous bodily harm in respect of the Odisho and Zakaria shootings, while the offenders are to be sentenced for soliciting murder in each case and attempted murder in the case of Odisho. Witness M was sentenced for accessory before the fact to the murder of Mahmoud Hamzy, whereas the offenders are to be sentenced for manslaughter. Witness L was sentenced for wounding with intent to cause grievous bodily harm in relation to the Hamzy shooting.
	
	
	The differences in the charges gives rise to difficulties in the application of the parity principle but, as the High Court emphasised in Green v The Queen; Quinn v The Queen, equal justice requires that the sentence imposed on each of the co-offenders be considered carefully to ensure that the sentences imposed on the Qaumi brothers are proportionate and do not leave them with a justifiable sense of grievance.
	
	
	Apart from the different charges, there are also significant differences in the personal case of each offender and in their criminal histories. All of the co-offenders received reductions for their pleas and assistance and I have considered the “starting point” in applying the parity principle and in determining the appropriate sentence for the three offenders in respect of any offence where a co-offender has already been sentenced. Where an aggregate sentence was imposed on the co-offender, I have considered the “indicative sentence” nominated by the sentencing Judge under s 53A(2)(b) of the Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act.
	
	
	All of the sentences imposed on the co-offenders are significant to the proper exercise of the sentencing discretion, but the most significant to my mind are the sentences imposed on Witness M for her involvement in the Hamzy shooting and Witness L for his involvement in both the Hamzy shooting and the Antoun murder.
	
	
	I have applied the principles of parity and proportionality in sentencing the offenders. I have considered the sentences imposed on the co-offenders. I have also considered a comparison of the sentences as between the three brothers themselves to ensure that there is equal (or proportionate) justice between them and that none of them is left with a justifiable sense of grievance.
	
	
	As between the three brothers, and speaking generally rather than in relation to any particular offence, principles of equal justice require the total sentencing outcome for Farhad to be more punitive than that of his brothers. That is because he was the undisputed and greatly feared leader of the gang. He also has a worse criminal history and, in spite of his sympathetic personal history, there is nothing in the evidence in his case that allows for a positive finding in relation to rehabilitation. The sentence he receives must be calculated to protect the community from the kind of violence that he and his gang unleashed during the last two months of 2013. Again, because of his youth and relatively unblemished criminal history, Jamil Qaumi can expect to receive a sentence of shorter duration than that imposed on his brothers. Within the different offences, different considerations apply. For example, Jamil and Farhad offered to plead guilty to the manslaughter of Mahmoud Hamzy and the sentence they receive will reflect that. Jamil asked for serious offences to be taken into account in sentencing for the manslaughter and that will increase the weight given to retribution and specific deterrence in relation to that charge. While the offenders were acting together, Mumtaz Qaumi was far less active in the preparations for the Zakaria shooting, a fact reflected in the jury’s verdicts. The individual sentences must reflect these differences.
	


Totality, concurrence and accumulation, aggregate sentencing


	
	The first step in this complex exercise is to determine an appropriate sentence for each individual offence. It is then necessary to make decisions about the extent to which those sentences should be ordered to be served concurrently or cumulatively. If the sentences are accumulated, it is necessary to stand back at the end of the process and determine whether the overall sentence is correct having regard to the principle of totality.
	
	
	This process is made easier by the provision in section 53A of the Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act. That section provides that a sentencing Judge “may, in sentencing an offender for more than one offence, impose an aggregate sentence of imprisonment with respect to all or any 2 or more of those offences instead of imposing a separate sentence of imprisonment for each.” If the Court imposes an aggregate sentence, it “must indicate to the offender” that an aggregate sentence is to be imposed and the sentence that would have been imposed for each offence had separate sentences been imposed. [57] 
	
	
	In Cahill v R [58]  and Glare v R, [59]  the requirement in s 53A(2)(b) was considered. It is necessary to indicate the individual sentences that would have been imposed “after taking into account such matters as are relevant under part 3 or any other provision of this Act”. This means that I must indicate the putative sentences that would have been imposed having considered all relevant principles of sentencing, taking into account the aggravating and mitigating features under s 21A and any discounts (such as the reduction for the offers to plead guilty to manslaughter in Farhad and Jamil Qaumi’s cases). [60] 
	
	
	Section 44(2C) of the Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act provides that it is not necessary to indicate the individual non-parole periods that would have been imposed had an aggregate sentence not been imposed. [61]  However, in those counts to which a standard non-parole period applies, s 54B(4) requires me to indicate the non-parole period that I would have set. The insertion of s 45(1A) in 2016 provides a possible discretionary exception to this requirement. It is difficult to read the two provisions in conformity with one another and I propose to indicate a non-parole period in most cases that would result from the application of s 44 and in the absence of a finding of special circumstances.
	
	
	In a case such as the present, these provisions create what seem to be unnecessary complication and technicality but I must do my best to comply with them. Subject to a determination of whether a life sentence is to be imposed on Farhad or Mumtaz Qaumi for the Antoun murder, I propose to impose an aggregate sentence in relation to all offences except for the contempt charges against Jamil and Mumtaz Qaumi. I propose to impose fixed term sentences for the contempt charges and to commence the aggregate sentence at the conclusion of the sentence for those offences. I do this because the contempt offences are separated by time and circumstance from the other offences. It is also appropriate that the Court be seen to impose a clear and separate punishment for offences involving contempt in the face of the Court.
	
	
	Because an aggregate sentence is to be imposed, it is not necessary to indicate the degree to which I would have accumulated, or to indicate the method of staggering the commencement dates in order to achieve an appropriate balance between cumulation and concurrence. [62]  However, all of the offences are serious and the imposition of an aggregate sentence “is not to be used to minimise the offending conduct, or obscure or obliterate the range of offending conduct or its totality”. [63]  What must ultimately be achieved is an aggregate sentence commensurate with the totality of the criminality in each offender’s case. In relation to the offences targeting the BFL Bankstown, it will be born in mind that the offenders are charged with a number of offences that took place over a period of around a week and that, in some instances, they are charged with more than one offence arising out of the same criminal enterprise. For example, count 4 (soliciting the murder of Michael Odisho) comprises more or less the same acts as count 5 (intent to murder Michael Odisho). The same applies with respect to a number of firearms offences. If individual sentences were imposed for those two counts, it would be expected that there would be a large degree of concurrency and some degree of accumulation. All of these matters must be taken into account in determining the appropriate aggregate sentence for what is a most serious series of criminal offences.
	


Offer to plead guilty to manslaughter in respect of the Hamzy shooting


	
	The parties agreed that on 15 February 2016, Farhad Qaumi offered to plead guilty to the manslaughter of Mahmoud Hamzy. This was part way through a pre-trial hearing that commenced in November 2015 and concluded in April 2017. It was a late offer to plead but well before the trial actually commenced. The offer was not accepted by the prosecution but was vindicated by the jury’s verdict of not guilty of murder but guilty of manslaughter. There was no offer to plead guilty to any other charge. Had the offer been accepted, the trial would have proceeded over a number of months but there would have been some saving in court time. It had some, if rather limited, utilitarian value.
	
	
	The parties agreed that on 16 March 2016, Jamil Qaumi made a similar offer. Again, there was no offer in relation to any other charge and the Crown rejected the offer. This offer to plead guilty was even later than that made by Farhad Qaumi. Its utilitarian value was also limited but it had some capacity to save court time.
	
	
	A number of cases have considered the approach that should be taken by a sentencing Judge when the prosecution rejects an offender’s offer to plead guilty to an offence for which they are ultimately to be sentenced. [64]  As Hidden J said in R v Cardoso it would be “unacceptable” “if the measure of leniency afforded to an offender [who was] prepared to plead guilty to a lesser charge fairly available on the evidence, would depend on the Crown’s attitude.” [65] 
	
	
	I intend to reduce the sentences of Farhad and Jamil Qaumi in relation to the manslaughter of Mahmoud Hamzy by about 10% based on their late offer to plead guilty.
	


Commencement date


	
	The parties agree that any sentence imposed on Farhad Qaumi should commence on 9 January 2014, the day he went into custody in relation to these or related matters.
	
	
	Mumtaz Qaumi went into custody on 9 January 2014. However, he was sentenced in 2015 for an offence of “inmate possess mobile phone/SIM card etc”. [66]  That sentence was reduced on appeal to the District Court and replaced by a sentence of seven months with a non-parole period commencing 14 October 2015 and expiring 13 April 2016. This creates a complication in terms of the commencement date of the sentence. The Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act provides a wide discretion as to the commencement date. [67]  Considering principles of totality, the offence for which Mumtaz was sentenced was a very minor one in the context of the current sentencing exercise. However, it is separate offending and there should be some very small degree of accumulation. I propose to order that the sentences imposed on Mumtaz Qaumi will commence on 9 February 2014. That is to say, there will be an accumulation of one month but the earlier sentence will otherwise be subsumed by the current sentences.
	
	
	Jamil Qaumi went into custody on 7 November 2013. On 26 May 2017 he was sentenced to 2 months for two counts of common assault involving throwing a milk carton containing a substance at two corrective services officer. [68]  The suspicion was that the substance was urine (and that is what the charge sheet says) because Jamil yelled the words “how do like the taste of piss you dog cunt” after throwing the carton. However, the agreed facts state that the substance was water. While the Crown fairly concedes that I could make this sentence wholly concurrent, in my view it should be marked by some degree of extra punishment. I take the same approach to that adopted in Mumtaz’s case. The commencement date for the first of the contempt offences will be 7 December 2013.
	


Conditions of incarceration


	
	At the conclusion of the two day sentencing hearing on 7 April 2017, the offenders asked for time to obtain evidence of their conditions of incarceration. The matter came back before the Court on 26 April 2017. An affidavit of Jamil Qaumi was tendered. [69]  The Crown did not object to the affidavit and did not seek to cross-examine Jamil on its contents. [70]  The Crown and counsel for Farhad and Mumtaz Qaumi then sought more time to obtain additional evidence in relation to this issue. The matter was adjourned until 23 May 2017 when the issue was litigated over many hours, with the Court sitting well beyond 4:00pm to ensure that the evidence and submissions on sentence might, finally, come to an end. [71] 
	


The evidence


	
	Affidavits by Farhad and Mumtaz Qaumi were read and marked as exhibits and each was cross-examined. [72]  Three Corrective Services Officers provided affidavits, gave evidence and were cross-examined. [73] 
	
	
	The Crown Prosecutor also sought to tender a statement of Detective Inspector Patton (and a folder full of attachments) and there was a lengthy legal argument as to the admissibility of large parts of the document. [74]  I admitted the statement provisionally, restricted cross-examination to certain parts and subsequently ruled parts of the document to be inadmissible. The statement provided extracts of recorded telephone conversations involving one or more of the three offenders. The material fell into three broad categories.
	
	
	First, evidence of the offenders describing their custodial conditions in uncomplaining, if not glowing, terms. For example, on 2 December 2013 (before he went into custody on this occasion), Farhad told his mother “we call it Silverwater Hotel … they are now in a hotel mom”. Similarly, on 12 March 2015, Mumtaz agreed with another inmate that being “in the main” [part of the gaol] was like a “five star retreat”. There was also a conversation in which Jamil told a friend that he trained twice a day. This type of evidence was obviously relevant and admissible on the issue of whether the custodial conditions were so onerous that it might be treated as a reason to ameliorate the length of the sentence. However, the evidence is not of great significance. The comments made by Farhad Qaumi were made before he was in custody and, given the timing of events, are open to the interpretation that he was trying to comfort his mother after the arrest of her youngest son (Jamil). The comments of Mumtaz and Jamil appeared to have been made when they were in the “main” part of the gaol and had access to the type of facilities that they were generally denied while on remand.
	
	
	The second broad category of evidence led through Detective Patton involved the offenders discussing the commission of offences while in custody. This included offences of violence (Farhad and Mumtaz discussing stabbing another inmate) and bringing contraband into the gaol (Jamil discussing a friend bringing steroids into the prison). The Crown’s position was that this evidence supported its case that the offenders were in onerous custodial conditions as a result of their own misconduct. The offenders objected on the grounds that there was no evidence that these conversations were brought to the attention of prison authorities and no evidence that they played any part in the offender’s classification or designation that led them to be held in the conditions of which they complained. In evidence, Inspector Patton said that he caused some of the material to be brought to the attention of prison authorities. However, he could not say who he told, and his evidence was imprecise as to what was communicated. He agreed that he did not provide (or cause to be provided) the recordings themselves to the prison authorities. There was no clear or direct evidence from the Corrective Services Officers (or otherwise) to support the proposition that these recordings played any role in the classification of the offenders as high security inmates or as inmates who should be segregated (either for the safety of others or their own protection). The timing of when the offenders received their various classifications and designations does not support the contention that the information provided by Mr Patton played any part in these classifications. While the evidence is before me, it is entitled to little weight and I must be cautious not to allow extraneous information concerning other wrongdoing, or threatened wrongdoing, to influence an assessment of an appropriate sentence.
	
	
	The third aspect of Detective Patton’s evidence was that the recorded ‘phone calls (or some of them) were made on contraband mobile telephones. Mumtaz Qaumi was convicted in the Local Court of being an inmate in possession of a mobile telephone [75]  and Farhad Qaumi had a disciplinary charge of possessing “a mobile” as well as a charger and SIM card. As with the second broad category of evidence, there was no evidence of any link between these breaches and the conditions of custody in which the offenders are held. Again, while taking the matter into account in assessing the prosecution’s submission that the offenders are the authors of their own fate, I am unable to give this matter very much weight.
	
	
	I generally accept the evidence given by the three offenders. Jamil Qaumi’s evidence was not challenged in cross-examination and I found Mumtaz and Farhad Qaumi to be reliable in their account of their custodial conditions. Some of what they said was supported by the evidence of the Corrective Services Officers. I am conscious of the fact that they may have exaggerated the onerous nature of the conditions to some degree but the important parts of their evidence were worthy of credit. I accept that each of the offenders has spent long periods in virtual isolation, or solitary confinement, that they have not had access to programmes, gym equipment and, most significantly, access to the outside spaces. I accept they are subject to strict security during legal visits and when they are transported from gaol to gaol or from gaol to court. It is difficult to reconcile some of the evidence of their restricted ability to have visits with the records tendered by the Crown. However, overall, I accept that these conditions are more onerous than is generally the case.
	
	
	I also generally accept the evidence given by the officers of the Department of Corrective Services although there may have been an inclination to downplay the harshness of the conditions. There was also a deal of general evidence as to how the system of classification works without much detail as to how it applied to the individual offenders. Still, each of the officers was an honest and straightforward witness.
	
	
	Philip Hugil is the Director of Classification and Placements for the Department. [76]  He explained the classification and designation of the three offenders and the grounds upon which they have been given those classifications. He explained the role of the Commissioner and the review process. He was unable to provide evidence as to the material that led to the particular classification of the three offenders. However, in general, it is based on an assessment of the risk that a prisoner poses to other inmates, to the staff at the gaol and to security issues within the gaol. Farhad was classified A-1 and Jamil and Mumtaz classified A-2. In addition, each was designated as an “Extreme High Security” inmate. This means that the Commissioner has determined that they represent an extreme danger to other people and to the good order and security of a correctional centre. Each received this designation on the basis of their “criminal antecedents and behaviour in custody”. Those are the criteria, but Mr Hugil was unable to say what the specific basis of this designation was in each case because those decisions were taken before he took over his position. Mr Hugil agreed, on the basis of documents shown to him, that Mumtaz Qaumi was kept in a “non-association cell” in spite of his request not to be placed in protection.
	
	
	Thomas Woods is the Acting Governor of the Silverwater Correctional Centre. [77]  This is where Jamil and Mumtaz Qaumi have been incarcerated for a large proportion of their remand period. It is also where Farhad was detained during the trial. Mr Woods described the conditions within the facility and gave evidence of the fact that each offender has been, at times, held in segregation. This means they have limited ability to interact with other inmates. His affidavit asserted that “[Jamil] will still be able to interact verbally with his brothers as well as other inmates housed in the same location via adjoining yards.” However, he agreed in cross-examination that any such interaction would be “by yelling over a very high [about 3 metres] wall.” There is no “face to face contact”. This is an example of the tendency to understate the harshness of the conditions. On reading Mr Woods’ affidavit, I formed the impression that the offenders could have face to face, human contact with one another. That was a false impression.
	
	
	Mr Woods agreed that there was no exercise equipment and no employment or educational opportunities. Mr Woods said that Jamil was in the Silverwater gaol because his solicitors requested he be available for legal visits. Otherwise, he may have been transferred to a gaol outside of Sydney. However, because of his classification, designation and the non-association status, the conditions would have been similar. In his affidavit, Mr Woods said that Jamil was held in segregation because of an assault on two inmates. [78]  This was not correct. At the further hearing on 13 June 2017 (concerning Jamil’s Qaumi’s post incarceration assault conviction), it was indicated that the assault involved throwing water (believed to be urine) on two prisoner officers. [79]  Mr Woods confirmed that his gaol is a remand centre and that, after sentence is imposed, Jamil and Mumtaz will be transferred to another gaol.
	
	
	Geoffrey Poulsen is the Senior Assistant Superintendent of the High Risk Management Correctional Centre at Goulburn. [80]  He described the general conditions of this facility, commonly known as the “Supermax”. This is where Farhad Qaumi has been housed for a good deal of his remand period. During the trial he was held at Silverwater. Mr Poulsen was a blunt but impressive witness. He conceded a number of matters suggesting the conditions at the gaol are very onerous and the opportunity for interaction with other inmates limited. Things like the use of exercise facilities, visits by friends and relatives and the use of the telephone are highly regulated. He disagreed that Farhad Qaumi only had access to the exercise yard for one hour per day. He did not accept that A1 prisoners like Farhad were unable to interact with AA prisoners (generally, it seems, people charged with or convicted of terrorism offences). Farhad Qaumi was on the “top level” of entitlements as a result of his good behaviour. This meant for example, he was able to book time to use a chin up bar and basketball court. Mr Poulsen was unable to say when, if ever, Farhad Qaumi would get out of the Supermax.
	


The issues and legal principles


	
	This evidence and the submissions that followed gave rise to a number of legal and factual issues relevant to the sentencing discretion.
	
	
	The first is that the courts are reluctant to interfere with, or second-guess, the management of prisons and inmates by those charged with the responsibility of administering them. [81]  In Kelleher v Commissioner, Department of Corrective Services McInerney J said at [11]:
	


"The exercise of powers relating to prisoner classification and separation, the transfer from one part of a prison to another, transfers between prisons, conditions on visits or access to certain conditions or facilities such as education, recreation and supply of condoms have all been characterised as administrative and managerial in nature rather then punitive and judicial. Consequently, they have been held not to give rise to any right, interest or legitimate expectation enforceable by judicial review in the ordinary courts. For example, see Smith v Commissioner of Corrective Services (1978) 1 NSWLR 317; Walker v The Queen (1992) 60 A Crim R 463; Gray v The Queen (1990) 45 A Crim R 364; and Prisoners A-XXX inclusive (1935) 38 NSWLR 622."


	
	The second is that a sentencing Court is entitled to take into account the conditions of incarceration in which an offender has been, is being, or will be held. If those conditions are harsher than those of the general prison population, it is a matter that may provide a basis for reducing the sentence to some degree. [82]  However, there must be evidence of the conditions upon which the Court can safely act. [83]  A sentencing judge cannot assume that the conditions will be harsher based on the category of inmate into which the offender fits.
	
	
	Third, in the absence of clear evidence, it is difficult for a sentencing Judge to predict the conditions in which the offender might serve the future part of the sentence. [84]  That is true in this case. There is nothing to suggest that the offenders will be placed in less onerous (and more humane) conditions in the near future. However, according to the evidence, there is some opportunity for their conditions to change depending on their behaviour while in custody. However, many of the matters that determine their classification, designation and non-association status are unlikely to change and are beyond their control. This is partly because, as Farhad Qaumi put it in evidence, “I’m at war”. [85] 
	
	
	Fourth, where the offender’s conditions of custody result from their own misconduct while in custody, the offender cannot rely on those conditions to any significant degree. For example, if the offender has committed acts of violence towards other inmates and this causes them to be held in segregation, the offender cannot be heard to complain or expect any reduction in sentence as a result of those conditions. [86] 
	
	
	Fifth, “there is no automatic conclusion or formula to be applied in the absence of evidence in a particular case”. [87]  In fact, there is no automatic conclusion or formula at all. Each case must be determined on its own facts. It is a matter that may be taken into account but it does not result in some mathematical reduction in an otherwise appropriate sentence.
	
	
	Finally, the Crown submitted that the conditions of incarceration would only be taken into account as a “special circumstance” justifying a small reduction in the length of the non-parole period. [88]  According to the Crown’s submission, this meant that if I determined to impose a life sentence, the matter could not be taken into account at all. [89]  When this proposition was tested by taking an extreme example, the Crown maintained that the conditions in which an offender was to be incarcerated was “not a relevant consideration” in determining whether a life sentence under s 61(1) Crimes (Sentencing Procedure) Act should be imposed. [90]  As I said in the course of the argument, I am unable to accept that submission. I will explain my approach to s 61(1) later in this judgment. In any event, the submission that the matter is only (or predominantly) relevant to the assessment of the non-parole period is contrary to the judgment of Howie J in Durocher-Yvon at [20]:
	


“Although the question in that case [was] concerned with whether there should have been a finding of special circumstances, the same considerations seem to me to apply to the question of whether the head sentence should be reduced.”


	
	I accept that the conditions in which each of the offenders has been held is harsh, perhaps unduly so. They have extremely limited opportunity to interact with other prisoners, are kept locked in their cells for extended periods, have little or no access to education and employment and are accommodated in small cells with very limited opportunity to access outside space.
	
	
	The reason for this is twofold, and perhaps in Jamil Qaumi’s case threefold. First, the offenders are classified as “high risk management” prisoners. This is the result of the number and nature of their criminal offending. While this is a matter within the province of the prison authorities, I accept Senior Counsel’s submission that there is element of “double punishment” at play. Second, they have been placed on the highest form of protection. This is partially because the offenders are “at war” [with the BFL Bankstown] and because they are perceived to represent a danger to other inmates and to the good order of the prison. It is not, as Senior Counsel for Mumtaz put it, a matter of “management expediency”. [91]  However, it is also because the authorities are concerned for the safety of the offenders themselves and because there are limited places where they can safely be accommodated. It is not because of any malevolent act of the offenders committed since they were taken into custody. While not perfect, the offenders’ disciplinary records since going into custody are not terrible (although since writing this part of the judgment it has emerged that Jamil Qaumi assaulted some prisoner officers). The third reason is that Jamil Qaumi’s lawyers requested that he be kept at Silverwater (MRRC) in order to facilitate visits during the currency of the criminal proceedings.
	


Resolution


	
	I accept it is appropriate to take into account the conditions of custody that have prevailed while the offenders have been on remand. It is not possible to determine how long into the future these conditions, or similar conditions, will prevail although I accept the submission that their status as high-risk management prisoners is unlikely “to change any time soon”. [92]  Accordingly, I propose to give the matter some weight in the assessment of an appropriate sentence. In the case of Jamil Qaumi, it is one matter that I consider on the question of whether there are “special circumstances” warranting an adjustment of the non-parole period. In the case of Farhad and Mumtaz Qaumi, it is a factor, albeit a minor factor in the scheme of things, in determining the question of whether a life sentence is warranted in accordance with the terms of s 61(1). It will be important not to “double count” the matter as a “special circumstance” if it is taken into account in determining the total sentence.
	


SENTENCE for jamil qaumi


	
	I turn to the sentence to be imposed on Jamil Qaumi.
	
	
	In almost every case, the Crown has submitted that it is appropriate to impose the maximum penalty. [93]  This submission did not distinguish between the offenders and, rarely, the offences.
	
	
	For example, the Crown submitted it would be open to impose the maximum penalty on all offenders in relation to the offence of conspiracy to murder Mahmoud Hamzy. [94]  However, in relation to that offence there is a strong, objective and mitigating feature inherent in the jury’s verdicts. That conspiracy was entered in circumstances where each of the offenders believed it was necessary to kill Mohammed Hamzy in order to protect the life of Farhad Qaumi. The jury asked a question in the course of its deliberation as to whether the law of self-defence applicable to murder applied to this count. [95]  The answer was “no”. [96]  This question must be considered in the light of the verdict on count 1 in which the jury did not find the first limb of self-defence negatived beyond reasonable doubt. In those circumstances, it is difficult to see how the Court would be justified in imposing the maximum penalty.
	
	
	In relation to the shooting offences at the Odisho and Zakaria homes, while the suggestion of self-defence was untenable, I do accept on balance that the offenders were motivated to a degree by their fear that members of the BFL Bankstown were motivated to seek revenge on them for the Hamzy shooting. That shooting, it must be recalled, occurred in the context that the BFL Blacktown had information that there was a plot to kill Farhad Qaumi. The same cannot be said of the Chokolatta Café shooting. There was nothing that would justify that shooting, even in the eyes of those who carried it out. Farhad himself had excluded the target, Abu-Mahmoud, from the “hit list”.
	
	
	In the case of Jamil Qaumi, his subjective case is such that he is not an appropriate vehicle for the imposition of the maximum penalty. He was only 21 years old at the time of the offending. He had a minimal criminal history, was newlywed and was acting under the influence of, and for the protection of his older brother, Farhad. His experience of an earlier drive-by shooting in which Farhad was targeted created the kind of paranoid response described by the psychologist and his sister. [97] 
	
	
	Even accepting all of those things and giving them a great deal of weight, the individual indicative sentences and the aggregate sentence imposed must reflect the wanton lawlessness and callousness in Jamil Qaumi’s outlandish behaviour.
	
	
	As I have said, I intend to impose separate sentences for the three contempt charges and accumulate upon those sentences an aggregate sentence for those offences in relation to which Jamil Qaumi was found guilty by the jury.
	
	
	To comply with relevant statutory provisions and case law following Muldrock v The Queen, it is necessary to do two things before proceeding to sentence. I must indicate whether those offences carrying a standard non-parole period fall within the middle range of objective seriousness and must provide an indicative sentence in relation to each of the offences.
	



	
	In relation to count 1, the manslaughter of Mahmoud Hamzy, taking into account the matters on the Form 1 and a discount of around 10% for the offer to plead guilty, I indicate a sentence of 12½ years.
	
	
	In relation to count 2, grievous bodily harm of Omar Ajaj, the offence is in the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of 8 years with a non-parole period of 6 years.
	
	
	In relation to count 3, conspiracy to murder Mohammed Hamzy, the offence is in the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of 10 years with a non-parole period of 7½ years.
	
	
	In relation to count 4, soliciting the murder of Michael Odisho, the offence is in the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of 10 years with a non-parole period of 7½ years.
	
	
	In relation to count 5, the attempted murder of Michael Odisho, the offence is in the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of 10 years with a non-parole period of 7½ years.
	
	
	In relation to count 7, soliciting the murder of Masood Zakaria, the offence in the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of 10 years with a non-parole period of 7½ years.
	
	
	In relation to count 9, grievous bodily harm of H with intent, the offence is above the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicated a sentence of 10 years with a non-parole period of 7½ years.
	
	
	In relation to count 10, soliciting the murder of Abdul Abu-Mahmoud, the offence is at, or just above, the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of 12 years with a non-parole period of 9 years.
	
	
	In relation to count 11, the attempted murder of Abudul Abu-Mahmoud, the offence is at, or just above, the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of 12 years with a non-parole period of 9 years.
	
	
	In relation to count 13, the attempted murder of Khalil Khalil, the offence is at, or just above, the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of 12 years with a non-parole period of 9 years.
	
	
	In relation to count 15, the attempted murder of Hassan Soueid, the offence is at, or just above, the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of 12 years with a non-parole period of 9 years.
	
	
	In relation to count 20, the large commercial supply of drugs, the offence is well below the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of four years with a non-parole period of three years. This is the same indicative sentence in the case of Witness L. [98] 
	
	
	In relation to count 21, the possession of the Mossberg sawnoff shotgun, the offence is in the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of 4 years with a non-parole period of 3 years.
	
	
	In relation to count 22, the possession of the 0.38 calibre Smith & Wesson revolver, the offence is in the middle range of objective seriousness and I indicate a sentence of 4 years with a non-parole of 3 years

	Jamil Qaumi:
	



	
	For the offence of contempt of court on 23 August 2016, you are sentenced to a fixed term of 4 months commencing on 7 December 2013 and concluding on 6 April 2014.

Accordingly, there will be a non-parole period of 21 years commencing 7 December 2014 and concluding on 6 December 2035 with a balance of parole of 9 years commencing 7 December 2035 and concluding 6 December 2044.
